resource.chars:
Section II. 
<u>Of the Affinities of the Medusae<\u> 
[paragraph].56. Certain general conclusions are deducible from the facts 
stated in the preceding section. It would appear 
1<sup>stly<\sup> That a <u>Medusa<\u> consists essentially of two membranes 
enclosing a variously shaped cavity - inasmuch as its various 
organs are so composed ([paragraph] 7.8.14.21.22.29.33.38.39.&c.) 
2<sup>ndly<\sup> That the generative organs are external being variously 
developed processes of the two membranes ([paragraph].38.39.42.48.49.) and 
3<sup>rdly<\sup> That the peculiar organs called thread cells are universally 
present ([paragraph].7.15.31.32.) 
Now in these particulars the <u>medusae<\u> present a striking resemblance to certain other families of <u>Zoophytes<\u>. These are 
the <u>Hydroid<\u> and <u>Sertularian Polypes<\u> the <u>Physophoridae<\u> and 
the <u>Diphydae<\u>  with all of which the same three propositions 
hold good* 
----------------
*Note. "Les parois du tube nutritif sont formees d'une double 
membrane toujours soudee intimement dans cette partie du 
polypier, l'externe repond aux teguments, l'interne est une 
continuation de la membrane digestive de la capacite 
alimentaire" <u>Cuvier. Org. d. Generation des Zoophytes. Lecons d'Anat. Comp. T.viii 2<sup>me<\sup>. ed<sup>n<\sup><\u> 
I have elsewhere pointed out that the same circumstance obtains 
among the Diphydae & Physophoridae - 
That the Generative organs are external in the Sertularian & Hydroid Polypes 
has been long known - Milne Edwards has shown that they have a 
similar position in one of the Physophoridae (Apolemia) - I have observed 
it myself in the Diphydae 
The presence of the thread cells has been determined by Will in the Diphydae 
by Milne Edwards in Apolemia by myself (only??) in Physalia, Physophora, 
Athorybia & other Physophoridae and in the Sertularian Polypes -- 
1
